title: We need more stories from the perspective of ordinary people in Runeterra.
body:
If there's one thing that truly makes me appreciate how awesome a character is it's when they're [juxtaposed](http://www.dictionary.com/browse/juxtaposed) to a regular Joe.

And, while I'm regular Joe, I don't live on Runeterra and, as such, I'm unfamiliar with the day-to-day events that are caused by/involve these 'Legends'.

So, from the perspective of a gamer, the greatness of these champions are pretty standard in that universe. I feel like I could more appreciate the epicness of the characters if I can see what they mean to regular people.

Are some of them too dangerous in the public's eye? Are some the only reason their lives are even held together? Would the general public be better off without them? Do they solves problems that a normal person couldn't? Does that cause laziness and dependence? Do they create more problems than they're worth? Does that cause the public to see them all in the same light? Ex.: "How long before Garen becomes the next Darius?"

Making champions as awesome and amazing as you can doesn't amount to much when people only view that level of greatness as the standard.

replies.body: Quite a few are told from the perspective of rather ordinary folk. Rek'Sai's entire teaser was told from the perspective of a Noxian surveyor. Tea with the Gray Lady is told from the perspective of a thug. The same applies to Urgot's story. The Vastayan Field Journal is, I feel, a good example of how mundane humans perceive the Vastaya. If you wanted to go outside the literary medium, Warwick, Rek'Sai, and Kalista's teasers do a wonderful job of portraying just how terrifying these champions can be.

Hey Bio, this might be slightly off-topic, but will we have more stories where our supernatural/extraterrestrial Champions are exceptionally vulnerable? I really enjoyed the Bilgewater and Demacia (Lux, Garen) stories for that reason (the human element), but champions like Eve/Tahm/Kha'Zix/Cho'Gath don't suffer in the same sense. What would suffering be for them exactly?

> [{quoted}](name=Jasiwel,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Ze1Ycbgv,comment-id=00010000000000000001,timestamp=2017-10-25T16:59:44.379+0000)
>
> Hey Bio, this might be slightly off-topic, but will we have more stories where our supernatural/extraterrestrial Champions are exceptionally vulnerable? I really enjoyed the Bilgewater and Demacia (Lux, Garen) stories for that reason (the human element), but champions like Eve/Tahm/Kha'Zix/Cho'Gath don't suffer in the same sense. What would suffering be for them exactly?

I'm not sure what's coming up for those champs specifically, but in terms of what their suffering looks like - for all of them, it would be hunger/starvation.  They all exist to consume (pain, misery, magic, or biological matter) and if they were prevented from doing so, I strongly believe they'd experience suffering as powerfully as they experience satisfaction from sating their hunger.

We get a hint of that with Evelynn - as she is continually seeking greater and greater sources of pain to feed from, but is unable to get satisfaction.  There's the sense that her needs are becoming stronger - perhaps even stronger than she knows how to seek out - which may drive her to more and more extreme methods until she's stopped.

It's probably unlikely that we'll see a lot of that though - the champs you listed are so valuable as opposition to many of our other champs that they need to, for the most part, be powerful and incredibly dangerous.  Also, their power is a lot of their draw for many players - there's something very attractive about picking a champ that's just.  so.  unstoppable.
Just the kind of response I was hoping for, thank you so much!
Love the Piltover stories ^^ Also love Magga's POV in [A Good Death](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/page/good-death)

Tbh I feel like the reason people want more interactions is because there barely is any.I love seeing the views from the common people as well (training day also being my favorite) but I know I would love to see interactions with the whole du couteau family more than anything. As of right now there's just alot of world building and setting up stories but we dont get to see it play out (like a sequel to the stories I guess) and usually with interactions you can see how far certain champs have come with their journey or just see more of a champs personality.

A tale from the Zaun market place.

"Hey, what happened to Waltz? Didn't he use to serve here."
'Poor bastard. He ran a foul with that purple menace of a doctor.'
"What about his brother?"
'Mauled by a werewolf.'
"And their boss?"
'Big cyborg spider guy put him through a meat grinder.'
"Is their house for sale then?"
'Blown up by a crazy lady talking to her guns.'
"Shame that. It was a good place. Take care then."
'And you. Stay out of the smog now.'

I think this is a good idea but...at the same time, a lot of champs are just regular or above-average people.

There's nothing inherently special about {{champion:51}}. She's good at her job. She's got good aim. But she's not the best markswoman who ever lived or the greatest cop in the history of Runeterra. (Well, not in her new lore). It's hard to juxtapose some of these characters because they're really just people good at what they do.

Ok.

Half of all the lore is from the civilian's perspective already. Yet OP's thread pretends like that's not being represented enough and receives tons of support as if the community is in agreement... what is this weird hypocrisy?

> [{quoted}](name=Whyte Lyon,realm=OCE,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Ze1Ycbgv,comment-id=0004,timestamp=2017-10-24T21:19:00.555+0000)
>
> Half of all the lore is from the civilian's perspective already. Yet OP's thread pretends like that's not being represented enough and receives tons of support as if the community is in agreement... what is this weird hypocrisy?

I mean, I did specifically say "more" as in "The amount we have is good. But I would like more."

I didn't imply there wasn't any or 'enough'.

Likewise, a lot of the perspectives we get are from either people who are about to be killed by the champ or people who are viewing the champ. I don't feel like we really got a normal person in Runeterra who we actually cared about and valued their opinion. If you feel otherwise, that's fine.

...
Asking for an increase of something that is already been represented to a successful extent seems weird to me. It's like asking for many more superhero movies when the film industry is already saturated, with more guaranteed to come.

Personally I would go a step further. I want a hero to be a normal type guy. I’ve proposed a few times I would love a champion who was a Demacian infantryman. Not a glorious warrior-knight, not a secret mage, not a prince. I want a common conscript to see how the other half lives. 

He can go through a hero arc, sure. But start him out unimportant. Let’s watch the guy earn the status of legend.
